desc.size: Annual herb, to 20 cm tall, erect.

part.partText: single or multiple from the base, from a small taproot, branching, erect, purplish, with densely appressed forked hairs.

alternate, stalked, egg-shaped, tips rounded to slightly pointed, margins typically with two small teeth. Leafstalks to 5 mm long and flattened. The leaves and leafstalks are densely covered with appressed forked hairs like the stem.
alternate, stalkless, becoming lance-shaped to nearly linear, margins non-toothed, densely hairy.

in a dense, hairy, branched cluster (raceme), which is borne terminally and laterally on a stem. Sepals four, purplish. Petals four or none, erect to spreading, white or yellow, to 3 mm long, to 2 mm wide, rounded or with a slightly notched tip. Stamens six.
a pod (silicle), 2.5 - 4 mm long, 0.8 - 1.4 mm wide, flattened, oblong-elliptic, smooth.

similarSpecies.comments: Both Draba reptans and D. verna are similar but have leaves confined to the lower (D. reptans) and basal (D. verna) areas. The flowers of D. verna are deeply cleft, and the silicles of D. reptans are more than 5 mm long and 1.3 mm wide.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Known only from a single collection made in DeKalb County, Illinois, although unconfirmed reports exist. Look for it in lawns, fields, prairies, woods, roadsides, open sandy areas, and along railroads.

notes.comments: Apparently introduced to the Chicago Region from the southern states.

etymology.comments: Draba comes from the Greek word drabe (which was also once a Greek word for a cress plant), meaning sharp or acrid, which refers to the burning taste of the leaves.
